bibl.title: Letter from Carlos [F. Sacasa] to Philip Showalter Hench, January 8, 1942

div1.p: [Sacasa] informs Hench that Dodge will make overtures to his cousin, George Carroll. [Sacasa] discusses the personality of George Carroll.

div1.head: Letter from Carlos [F. Sacasa] to Philip Showalter Hench, January 8, 1942
div1.opener:
STEPHEN SMITH, M.D., F.A.C.P
MEDICAL DIRECTOR
CHAS. W. THOMPSON, M.D., F.A.C.P.
MEDICAL DIRECTOR
ETHEL FANSON, M.D.
CLIFTON H. BRIGGS, M.D., F.A.C.S.
DOUGLAS R. DODGE, M.D.
CARLOS F. SACASA, M.D.
BOARD OF DIRECTORS
------
GEORGE DOCK, M.D., PRES.
JAMES ROBERT SANFORD, M.D.
VICE-PRESIDENT
STEPHEN SMITH, M.D., F.A.C.P.
CHAS. W. THOMPSON, M.D., F.A.C.P.
LAS ENCINAS SANITARIUM
PASADENA, CALIFORNIA
Jan 8, 1942 Dr. P. S. Hench
Rochester, Minn.
My dear Dr Hench:
div1.p:
I have talked to Dr. Dodge and his
mother and both are extremely interested in the yellow
fever matter. Dr. Dodge said he could write his cousin
and may be has already done so. He is not here tonight
but I shall make sure tomorrow morning. Dr. Dodge
said that George Carroll has always been very peculiar
and believes that his attitude toward you in the past may
be due to the fact that following Dr Carroll's death his
mother became “afflicted” with a “hero-worship complex” on
her husband and for hours would talk about his heroic
courage, etc., and this used to get on George's hair.

George's wife has been an invalid for
years and have heard that she is badly crippled
from arthritis.

Before her marriage Mrs. Dodge lived
for some time with Dr. and Mrs Carroll in Baltimore
and of course, knows quite a bit about him.

I understand that George Carroll is the
owner of a sign shop in Washington, D. C., but you
probably know this and his address anyway.

Hope you will be more successful with
him this time. If I can do anything else, dont
hesitate to let me know.

Best regards to you, Mrs Hench and
the children.
